defect_desc:
Dengan ini kami sampaikan bahwa terdapat defect pada pesawat, yaitu seluruh lavatory tidak dapat melakukan flush saat pesawat berada di ground.
 Kerusakan ini telah berlangsung cukup lama dan sampai saat ini belum mendapatkan tindakan perbaikan.
 
 Kondisi tersebut menimbulkan dampak pada Crew dan Penumpang mengalami kesulitan menggunakan lavatory, terutama saat proses boarding dan sebelum keberangkatan.
 Sehubungan dengan hal tersebut, mohon agar defect ini dapat segera di-follow up dan diprioritaskan perbaikannya demi kelancaran operasional dan kenyamanan penumpang.
 
 Atas perhatian dan kerja samanya, kami ucapkan terima kasih.
 
 Hormat saya,
 Kholisatun nasiroh

defect_desc:
Dear Safety Directorate Team,
 
 I would like to submit a safety report regarding a non-standard modification found on the cockpit sun shield assembly on both the Captain and First Officer sides.
 
 During preflight preparation, I identified that the sun shields were being secured using a plastic mineral-water bottle cap and tape, as shown in the attached photo. These items are not approved cockpit equipment and constitute Foreign Object Debris (FOD).
 
 This finding is particularly concerning considering that the company has just issued Notice to Pilot No. 38/NTP/OQ/XII/2025, dated 4 December 2025, which explicitly prohibits the presence or use of any unauthorized equipment in the cockpit during all phases of operation.
 
 Details of Finding:
 â€¢ Location: Cockpit â€“ Captain & FO side sun shield rails
 â€¢ Condition: Sun shield locking/retention mechanism modified with a plastic bottle cap and adhesive tape
 â€¢ Issue: Unapproved modification; presence of non-standard objects inside cockpit
 
 Safety Risks Identified:
 â€¢ Potential FOD hazard if the items detach during turbulence or sudden aircraft movement
 â€¢ Possible interference with cockpit systems or movement around the flight deck
 â€¢ Non-compliance with manufacturer standards and flight deck equipment configuration
 â€¢ Direct violation of the newly issued NTP on unauthorized cockpit equipment

STEP 1 : PERFORMED FUNCTIONAL TEST OF THE NORMAL EXTENSION AND RETRACTION NLG, RESULT SATISFIED (EXTENSION 14 SECONDS). STEP 2 : PERFORMED DVI NOSE GEAR DOOR OPERATION ROD MECHANISM RESULT GOOD. STEP 3: PERFORMED CHECK NLG DOOR CONTROL ROD  RESULT GOOD. STEP 4: PERFORMED CHECK NOSEGEAR DOORS CLEARANCES AND MISMATCHES RESULT GOOD. STEP 5 : PERFORMED DET INSPECTION NLG DOOR UPLOCL UNIT AND PN RESULT GOOD. STEP 6: PERFORMED VISUAL INSPECTION ROTATING ROD NOSE GEAR AFT CARGO DOOR RESULT GOOD. STEP 7: PERFORMED DET INSPECTION OF NLG MAIN DOOR HINGEES ON LEFT AND RIGHT SIDES RESULT GOOD. STEP 12: PERFORMED FNC TEST NORMAL EXTENSION AND ROTATOON NLG RESULT SATISFIED

defect_desc:
On 17 December 2025, Batik Air Flight ID7282 was a scheduled revenue flight from Soekarno-Hatta International Airport (CGK) to Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KUL), operated using a Boeing 737-800 aircraft, registration PK-LBW. The flight was crewed by one Pilot in Command (PIC), one Second in Command (SIC), and four cabin crew members. For this sector, the PIC acted as the Pilot Flying (PF), while the SIC acted as the Pilot Monitoring (PM).
 
 Prior to departure, the PIC conducted a walk-around inspection, and no abnormalities were observed. The aircraft technical status was normal, and this flight was the first sector of the day. The takeoff from CGK was uneventful.
 
 During the initial climb phase, when the landing gear lever was selected to UP, the nose landing gear and main landing gear indication lights remained illuminated, indicating that the landing gear did not retract as commanded. After completing the clean-up actions, the flight crew observed that the three green landing gear lights remained ON, confirming that the landing gear was still in the down and locked position.
 
 The flight crew subsequently performed the applicable Landing Gear Disagree Non-Normal Checklist (NNC) in accordance with the Boeing 737 procedures. A single gear UP/DOWN recycle was performed as per the checklist; however, the indication remained unchanged with three green lights still illuminated. All checklist actions were completed.
 
 The aircraft was then established in a holding pattern over LUVAX at 6,000 feet, with an indicated airspeed of approximately 215 knots, to allow the crew to manage the situation, review aircraft performance, and completed the necessary checks. During the holding, the PIC made a passenger announcement informing the cabin of the technical condition and contacted company frequency regarding the situation. After completing performance calculations and confirming the landing configuration, the flight crew decided to return to base (RTB) to CGK and informed the Air Traffic Control (ATC) requesting RTB due to technical.
 
 Coordination was conducted with ATC, and a visual check from the Soetta Tower confirmed that the landing gear was down and locked during the approach phase. 
 
 The aircraft conducted an ILS approach to Runway 25R and landed safely at Soekarno-Hatta International Airport. After landing, the aircraft vacated the runway via Taxiway N6 and proceeded to gate R57A. There were no injuries reported to passengers or crew during the occurrence. The aircraft declared Aircraft On Ground (AOG) for further maintenance action.

repair_resolution: REF TSM TASK 22-81-00-810-803-A. DO THE OP'S TEST OF THE AFS REF AMM 22-96-00-710-001 RESULT TEST PASS. DO THE GROUND SCANNING OF THE AFS REF AMM 22-91-00-710-001 RESULT NO FAULT DETECTED. DO A CHECK FOR 28 VDC AT FCU PIN B/Z IS AVAIL. PROBLEM WAS REPETITIVE. CLOSED AND REOPEN DMI DUE TO NEED PART.  REF AMM TASK 22-81-12-000-001-A AND 22-81-12-400-001-A REV.17 PERFORMED REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION OF THE FLIGHT CONTROL UNIT (FCU) C/O. REF SUBTASK 22-81-12-710-052-A DO THE OP'S TEST OF AFS, OP'S TEST INITIALIZATION OF THE FLIGHT PLAN AND LAND CAT 3 CAPABILITY TEST RESULT GOOD (TEST PASSED). DMI CLOSED.

defect_desc:
After ldg from DJJ-UPG the engineer inform us that there was a blood marks on the engine. He told us that there was only blood marks and there was no carcass found anywhere near/inside the engine (the wx on UPG was raining).
 
 The engineer ask if there was any anomalities on the engine, and we told him that there was no abnormalities on the engine in all phase of flight. After that the blood marks was cleaned by the engineer and it is good to go.
 
 The next flight from UPG-CGK everything was normal from start engine until shutdown engine on CGK. No abnormalities, normal operation. Safely landed on CGK.
 
 Delay arrival due to cleaning process and waiting for statement release from quality.

defect_desc:
FLIGHT OCCURRENCE REPORT
 (Safety & Compliance Concern)
 
 Date: 22 December 2025
 Name: Resi Sekar Wangi
 ID No.: 181643
 
 Flight Routes:
 â€¢ SUB â€“ PKN (ID 6135)
 â€¢ PKN â€“ SUB (ID 6134)
 â€¢ SUB â€“ BEJ (ID 6346)
 â€¢ BEJ â€“ SUB (ID 6347)
 
 Aircraft Registration: PK-BKQ
 
 
 EVENT DESCRIPTION
 
 During operations on aircraft PK-BKQ, two straps were observed beneath Door 4L, located under the long section of the slide container. The position of these straps presented a potential obstruction and did not fully meet the required clear area condition during door closure.
 
 
 SEQUENCE OF EVENTS
 1. Flight SUBâ€“PKN (ID 6135)
 Door 4L was not opened.
 2. At PKN (two-door boarding)
 Door 4L was opened for boarding.
 Upon opening, straps were seen hanging outside the aircraft from beneath the slide container.
 During door closure, the external area was confirmed clear; however, full internal verification was not possible because:
 â€¢ The straps were positioned beneath the slide container, and
 â€¢ The straps were not visible from the normal door-closing position.
 As a result, complete clear area verification could not be ensured in accordance with procedures.
 3. Post door closure
 During the Captainâ€™s walk-around inspection, one strap was found still hanging outside Door 4L.
 4. Coordination
 The occurrence was reported to the CBM and Engineering.
 The straps were identified as slide retention straps and were assessed as safe.
 
 
 SAFETY CONCERN
 
 Despite being assessed as safe, the condition raises the following safety and compliance concerns:
 â€¢ Non-compliance with door closing procedures requiring full clear area confirmation
 â€¢ Potential damage to the door or slide container
 â€¢ Possible impact on emergency slide deployment if the slide is not properly stowed
 â€¢ Dependence on walk-around findings rather than verification during door closure
 
 REQUEST FOR FOLLOW-UP
 
 To ensure safety and procedural compliance, an official review and clarification are requested regarding:
 1. The function and procedural status of the straps located beneath the Door 4L slide container
 2. Whether straps hanging outside the door are acceptable under current procedures
 3. The correct method for verifying a clear area when such straps are not visible during door closure
 4. Preventive or corrective measures to avoid recurrence
 
 
 This report is submitted as a safety and compliance concern to support safe, standardized, and compliant flight operations.
 
 
 Warm regards

 Airbus A320 / PK-BLC
 
 *FLIGHT* : ID 7059
 
 *ROUTE* : CGK-PLM
 ETD 10.00 UTC
 
 *OCCURRENCE DETAIL* 
 
 During the landing phase, the aircraft experienced a suspected bird strike. All engine parameters remained within normal limits, and the aircraft taxied to the assigned gate. After parking at the gate, the Pilot in Command (PIC) coordinated with the Engineer in Charge to assess the condition of the aircraft.
